pageProps.body:
Group Families

Remember to smile and say "cheese."

There are many different types, or "families", or groups. Five simple ones - cyclic, symmetric, alternating, abelian and dihedral; and all the rest, from Lie groups to the Tits group to the simple "gentle giant" group which has order 808 017 424 794 512 875 886 459 904 961 710 757 005 754 368 000 000 000808 017 424 794 512 875 886 459 904 961 710 757 005 754 368 000 000 000808 017 424 794 512 875 886 459 904 961 710 757 005 754 368 000 000 000; from the Cox ring to the Mordell-Weil group of elliptic surfaces, whose basis is provided by the Cox-Zucker machine.

This chapter is not concerned with any of those special cases, all of which have names that sound like either a '90s emo-rock boy-band, a stage-name for a WWE wrestler, or the pseudonym of an adult-film actor. Instead, we're concerned with symmetry groups: groups that arise from all the ways you could spin, flip, and kick around a physical object and respect its symmetries by still keeping its shape the same. We start off with:

Dihedral groups

: "Say my name."
"You're... you're (Z37×Z211)⋊ ((A8×A12)⋊Z2).{\displaystyle (\mathbb {Z} _{3}^{7}\times \mathbb {Z} _{2}^{11})\rtimes \,((A_{8}\times A_{12})\rtimes \mathbb {Z} _{2}).}(Z37​×Z211​)⋊((A8​×A12​)⋊Z2​)."
"You're goddamn right."

Dihedral groups describe the symmetries of a regular nnn-gon (in order: the pentagon, the hexagon, the heptagon, and the whyamIstillstudyingmathnowmylifeisgon.) To be exact, define such a shape geometrically as follows:

Definition. Call a regular nnn-gon a collection of nnn vertices in the complex plane, given in counterclockwise order starting from the real axis by

1,e2πin,e22πin,...,e(n−1)2πin…1, e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}, e^{2\frac{2\pi i}{n}},..., e^{(n-1)\frac{2\pi i}{n}}\dots1,en2πi​,e2n2πi​,...,e(n−1)n2πi​…

Thus define the dihedral group in terms of the isometries of the nnn-gon, as follows:

Definition. An isometry of a physical object (e.g. a polygon) is any transformation upon it that maintains the distances between its vertices: something that preserves the exact shape of the object and does not deform, stretch, or compress it in any way. This could be a translation, a reflection, or a rotation, to name just a few examples.

The dihedral group of an nnn-gon, denoted D2nD_{2n}D2n​, is the group of all actions performable on the nnn-gon within the complex plane C\mathbb{C}C that send the nnn-gon to itself; not only do these actions preserve distances, but they keep the nnn-gon in the exact same position.

For instance, notice that the polygon pictured above is symmetrical about the Re\text{Re}Re-axis; as such, a reflection about that axis will map the polygon to itself. A rotation about the origin by one of the interior angles - 900/7900/7900/7 degrees for a septagon - also satisfies this requirement.

More formally, suppose that each of these isometries can be described as functions of complex numbers: f,g:C→Cf, g: \mathbb{C \to C}f,g:C→C that map one complex number to another, mapping all the points of the nnn-gon to the exact same points - though not necessarily in the same order. Thus we have

Theorem. Let the dihedral group of a nnn-gon D2nD_{2n}D2n​ - the nnnth dihedral group - be defined formally as (D2n,∘,Id)(D_{2n}, \circ, Id)(D2n​,∘,Id) where the binary operation f∘gf \circ gf∘g for isometries f,g∈D2nf, g \in D_{2n}f,g∈D2n​ entails "performing ggg followed by fff", or a composition of fff and ggg; and IdIdId is the identity isometry, given by the complex-valued function Id(x)=xId(x) = xId(x)=x.

We propose that the triple (D2n,∘,Id)(D_{2n}, \circ, Id)(D2n​,∘,Id) satisfies all of the group axioms and has order 2n2n2n.

Proof.

Let's verify the group axioms one by one.

  1. Closure. Suppose that fff and ggg are both elements of D2nD_{2n}D2n​; by definition, they map the nnn vertices of the nnn-gon - d1,d2,...,dnd_1, d_2, ..., d_nd1​,d2​,...,dn​ - to d1,d2,...,dnd_1, d_2, ..., d_nd1​,d2​,...,dn​, though not necessarily in that order. As such,

    (f∘g)(d1,...,dn)=f(g(d1,...,dn))=f(d1,...,dn)=d1,...,dn(f \circ g)(d_1, ..., d_n) = f(g(d_1, ..., d_n)) = f(d_1, ..., d_n) = d_1, ..., d_n(f∘g)(d1​,...,dn​)=f(g(d1​,...,dn​))=f(d1​,...,dn​)=d1​,...,dn​

    playing extremely fast and loose with notation (f(d1,...,dn)f(d_1, ..., d_n)f(d1​,...,dn​) means not what you think it does, but instead the nnn complex numbers f(d1),f(d2),...,f(dn)f(d_1), f(d_2), ..., f(d_n)f(d1​),f(d2​),...,f(dn​).) Therefore, f∘gf \circ gf∘g is also an isometry and is an element of D2nD_{2n}D2n​.

  2. Associativity. ∘\circ∘ is a composition of functions, and is thus associative.

  3. Identity. The isometry IdIdId is an identity by definition.

  4. Inverse. The two functions fff and ggg that preserve the nnn-gon are:

  • Rotation by 2kπn\frac{2k\pi}{n}n2kπ​, given by f(z)=z⋅e2kπinf(z) = z \cdot e^{\frac{2k\pi i}{n}}f(z)=z⋅en2kπi​ for integers k=0,1,2,...,n−1k = 0, 1, 2, ..., n-1k=0,1,2,...,n−1. For example, f(z)=z⋅e2πinf(z) = z \cdot e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}f(z)=z⋅en2πi​ maps the point 111 to e2πine^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}en2πi​, e2πine^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}en2πi​ to e4πine^{\frac{4\pi i}{n}}en4πi​, and so on; until evey point is mapped to the next point going counterclockwise. This is a distance-preserving isometry because

    ∣f(z1)−f(z2)∣=∣e2kπin∣∣z1−z2∣=∣z1−z2∣|f(z_1) - f(z_2)| = |e^{\frac{2k\pi i}{n}}||z_1 - z_2| = |z_1 - z_2|∣f(z1​)−f(z2​)∣=∣en2kπi​∣∣z1​−z2​∣=∣z1​−z2​∣

    and is thus a member of D2nD_{2n}D2n​.

  • Reflection about the real axis, given by g(z)=zˉg(z) = \bar{z}g(z)=zˉ, the complex conjugate. This is also an isometry, as

    ∣g(z1)−g(z2)∣2=(z1ˉ−z2ˉ)(z1ˉ−z2ˉ)‾=(z1−z2)(z1−z2)‾=∣z1−z2∣2|g(z_1) - g(z_2)|^2 = (\bar{z_1} - \bar{z_2})\overline{(\bar{z_1} - \bar{z_2})} = (z_1 - z_2) \overline{(z_1 - z_2)} = |z_1 - z_2|^2∣g(z1​)−g(z2​)∣2=(z1​ˉ​−z2​ˉ​)(z1​ˉ​−z2​ˉ​)​=(z1​−z2​)(z1​−z2​)​=∣z1​−z2​∣2

    and thus ∣g(z1)−g(z2)∣=∣z1−z2∣|g(z_1) - g(z_2)| = |z_1 - z_2|∣g(z1​)−g(z2​)∣=∣z1​−z2​∣.

  • Both the reflection and the rotation have well-defined inverses that are contained within D2nD_{2n}D2n​: an arbitrary rotation has f−1(z)=z⋅e−k2πin=z⋅e(n−k)2πin∈D2nf^{-1}(z) = z\cdot e^{-k\frac{2\pi i}{n}} = z \cdot e^{(n-k)\frac{2\pi i}{n}} \in D_{2n}f−1(z)=z⋅e−kn2πi​=z⋅e(n−k)n2πi​∈D2n​, and the reflection is its own inverse.

Now all that's left to prove is that the rotation and the reflection are the only two possible elements of D2nD_{2n}D2n​.

Lemma. D2nD_{2n}D2n​ is entirely described by the set {Id,f,f2,...,fn−1,g,fg,f2g,...,fn−1g}\{Id, f, f^2, ..., f^{n-1}, g, fg, f^2 g, ..., f^{n-1} g\}{Id,f,f2,...,fn−1,g,fg,f2g,...,fn−1g}, where fff denotes rotation by 2πn\frac{2\pi}{n}n2π​ counterclockwise, ggg denotes reflection across the real axis, and IdIdId is the identity isometry.

Proof.

Suppose that h∈D2nh \in D_{2n}h∈D2n​ is an isometry in C\mathbb{C}C. By the properties of D2nD_{2n}D2n​, we know that as 111 is a point on the nnn-gon, h(1)h(1)h(1) must also be a point on the nnn-gon - h(1)=ek2πinh(1) = e^{k\frac{2\pi i}{n}}h(1)=ekn2πi​ for k=0,1,...,n−1k = 0, 1, ..., n-1k=0,1,...,n−1. Thus we have

(f−k∘h)(1)=f−k(h(1))=e−k2πinek2πin=1(f^{-k} \circ h)(1) = f^{-k}(h(1)) = e^{-k\frac{2\pi i}{n}}e^{k \frac{2\pi i}{n}} = 1(f−k∘h)(1)=f−k(h(1))=e−kn2πi​ekn2πi​=1

where fff is rotation by 2πn\frac{2\pi}{n}n2π​; as such the transformation r=f−k∘h∈D2nr = f^{-k} \circ h \in D_{2n}r=f−k∘h∈D2n​ keeps 111 invariant. As rrr is an element of D2nD_{2n}D2n​, it is an isometry; and thus the distance between r(1)r(1)r(1) and r(e2πin)r(e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}})r(en2πi​), a vertex connected to 111 by a single edge, must remain the same as the distance between 111 and e2πine^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}en2πi​ originally. r(e2πin)r(e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}})r(en2πi​) thus shares an edge with r(1)=1r(1) = 1r(1)=1; therefore either

r(e2πin)=e2πinr(e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}) = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}r(en2πi​)=en2πi​

in whose case rrr must be the identity isometry IdIdId, via the argument that rrr preserves distances and r(e−2πin)r(e^{-\frac{2\pi i}{n}})r(e−n2πi​) must still share an edge with 111 but cannot be r(e2πin)=e2πinr(e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}) = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}r(en2πi​)=en2πi​, and thus r(e−2πin)=e−2πinr(e^{-\frac{2\pi i}{n}}) = e^{-\frac{2\pi i}{n}}r(e−n2πi​)=e−n2πi​; and so on and so forth with all other vertices; as such

r=f−k∘h=Id, h=fkr = f^{-k} \circ h = Id,\ h = f^kr=f−k∘h=Id, h=fk

for k=0,1,...,n−1k = 0, 1, ..., n-1k=0,1,...,n−1; or, alternatively,

r(e2πin)=e−2πinr(e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}) = e^{-\frac{2\pi i}{n}}r(en2πi​)=e−n2πi​

meaning that

s=(g∘r)(e2πin)=e2πins = (g\circ r)(e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}) = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}s=(g∘r)(en2πi​)=en2πi​

where ggg is a reflection about the real axis; as such sss keeps both e2πine^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}en2πi​ and 111 invariant, and so by the above argument with rrr, sss is also the identity. Therefore

g∘r=Id, r=f−k∘h=g−1=g, h=fk∘gg \circ r = Id,\ r = f^{-k} \circ h = g^{-1} = g,\ h = f^k\circ gg∘r=Id, r=f−k∘h=g−1=g, h=fk∘g

proving the general result. Thus D2nD_{2n}D2n​ is completely described by the set {Id,f,f2,...,fn−1,g,fg,...,fn−1g}\{Id, f, f^2, ..., f^{n-1}, g, fg, ..., f^{n-1}g\}{Id,f,f2,...,fn−1,g,fg,...,fn−1g} with a total of 2n2n2n elements.

It's worth noting that D2dD_{2d}D2d​ is not abelian: for instance, a rotation followed by a reflection is not the same as a reflection followed by a rotation.

Permutation groups

How many ways can you arrange the letters of the word KILL-ME-NOW, ensuring that the dashes are not adjacent to each other and the knife is not adjacent to the student?

The puns strike again in Permutations and Cycles!

Cyclic groups

I knew a group theorist who once fought in World War II. Four sticks of C-4 were thrown at his feet and he literally just spun around in a circle without moving. Anyways, he's dead now.

Cyclic groups describe objects with rotational symmetry: triangles, benzene molecules, Shrek's head, and German windmills. Of course they can't call them rotational groups; that honor goes to SO(2)SO(2)SO(2), which does a great job at describing how a circle rotates and a piss-poor job at anything else. Not "symmetric groups", either; that title is reserved solely for permutation groups, which contain all the seventy bazillion ways you could take a list of things and scramble them up to make them less symmetric. Who the hell came up with these names!?

That's right, Galois did. Of course it was him. Now if anyone ever asks me "if you could have dinner with any historical figure, alive or dead, who would it be?", I would tell them 1) Galois, and 2) pretty fricking dead.

Galois died at the age of 20 from a newly-acquired diet of a bullet to the stomach. Contrary to what historians have posited, his death in a duel was no accident; in fact, it was due to two tortured math undergrads from the far future who invented a time machine solely to convince Galois to fight and stop him from unleashing any further horrors upon our world.

Cyclic groups are differentiated from dihedral groups in that they do not contain reflections; more importantly, however, is a single property that lends them the name "cyclic".

Definition. A cyclic group is a group with a generator element ω\omegaω whose set contains only the powers of ω\omegaω:

{ω0=Id,ω1,...,ωn,...}\{\omega^0 = Id, \omega^1, ..., \omega^{n}, ...\}{ω0=Id,ω1,...,ωn,...}

where ωk\omega^kωk for some k∈Zk \in \mathbb{Z}k∈Z denotes repeating the binary operation of the group kkk times with ω\omegaω on itself.

A special case of cyclic groups is the group CnC_nCn​ described by the set of nnnth roots of unity, under multiplication as its binary operation and 111 as its identity:

Cn=({z∈C ∣ zn=1},×,1)C_n = (\{z \in \mathbb{C}\ |\ z^n = 1\}, \times, 1)Cn​=({z∈C ∣ zn=1},×,1)

More precisely, CnC_nCn​ permits the elements 1,e2πin,e22πin,...,e(n−1)2πin1, e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}} , e^{2\frac{2\pi i}{n}}, ..., e^{(n-1)\frac{2\pi i}{n}}1,en2πi​,e2n2πi​,...,e(n−1)n2πi​, with the property that with ω=e2πin\omega = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{n}}ω=en2πi​, we have

Cn={ω0,ω1,...,ωn−1}.C_n = \{\omega^0, \omega^1, ..., \omega^{n-1}\}.Cn​={ω0,ω1,...,ωn−1}.

In this case, ω\omegaω - the smallest non-identity rotation in the group, that by 2πn\frac{2\pi}{n}n2π​ radians counterclockwise - is the generator of CnC_nCn​; by definition of ω\omegaω as a root of unity, nnn repeated actions of ω\omegaω on an object cycles back to the identity - ωn=1\omega^n = 1ωn=1. Such a group represents the complete list of the rotational symmetries of an nnn-gon.

It's worth noting, though, that cyclic groups need not be related to rotations. Consider the set of all numbers that exist in mod 5\text{mod }5mod 5:

C5=({0,1,2,3,4},+,0)C_5 = (\{0, 1, 2, 3, 4\}, +, 0)C5​=({0,1,2,3,4},+,0)

in which case each element is a "power" of the generator 111 (with aka^kak being defined as a+...+aa + ... + aa+...+a kkk times with addition being the binary operation to be repeated, and a0=0a^0 = 0a0=0). Under such a definition, we have 15=1+1+1+1+1=0 mod 51^5 = 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 0 \text{ mod 5}15=1+1+1+1+1=0 mod 5 - looping back to the identity. This is rather colorfully depicted by the multiplication table below:

In fact, Z\mathbb{Z}Z itself - or any group of the form nZn\mathbb{Z}nZ, for that matter - is a cyclic group; a set of (additive) powers of nnn that go on to infinity instead of looping back to bite its own tail like a better-behaved cyclic group would.

It's very much worth noting here, as a preface to things to come, that cyclic groups form what could be considered the basic building blocks of group theory: they are themselves formed from a single element - its generator - and in any other group, where if aaa is an element then aka^kak is an element by definition, the set

{Id,a,...,an−1}\{Id, a, ..., a^{n-1}\}{Id,a,...,an−1}

where an=Ida^n = Idan=Id is itself a cyclic group by definition. In fact, all abelian groups - themselves one of the simplest types of groups - can be constructed out of cyclic groups! To explore this concept more, we turn to one final idea to cap off the entire chapter.
